doc.after: The name Muhammad (/mÊËhÃ¦mÉd, -ËhÉËmÉd/)[24] means "praiseworthy" and appears four times in the Quran.[25] The Quran addresses Muhammad in the second person by his various appellations; prophet, messenger, servant of God ('abd), announcer (bashir)[QuranÂ 2:119], witness (shahid),[QuranÂ 33:45] bearer of good tidings (mubashshir), warner (nathir),[QuranÂ 11:2] reminder (mudhakkir),[QuranÂ 88:21] one who calls [unto God] (dÄâÄ«),[QuranÂ 12:108] light personified (noor)[QuranÂ 05:15], and the light-giving lamp (siraj munir)[QuranÂ 33:46]. Muhammad is sometimes addressed by designations deriving from his state at the time of the address: thus he is referred to as the enwrapped (al-muzzammil) in Quran 73:1 and the shrouded (al-muddaththir) in Quran 74:1.[26] In Sura Al-Ahzab 33:40 God singles out Muhammad as the "Seal of the Prophets", or the last of the prophets.[27] The Quran also refers to Muhammad as Aá¸¥mad "more praiseworthy" (Arabic: Ø£Ø­ÙØ¯â, Sura As-Saff 61:6).
